comment_text:
Some added notes (copied from the pinned commend to the next video):

1) Some people have asked about if the tan(x) ≈ x approximation, being off by only a cubic error term, is actually close enough not to affect the final count. It's actually a very interesting answer! I really went back and forth on whether or not to include this in the video but decided to leave it out to better keep things to the point. This difference between arctan(x) and x could be problematic for our final count if, at some point when you're looking at the first 2n digits of pi, the last n of them are all 9's. It seems exceedingly unlikely that this should be true. For example, among the first 100 million digits of pi, the maximal sequence of consecutive 9's has length 8, whereas you'd need a sequence of 50 million for things to break our count! Nevertheless, this is quite difficult to prove, related to the question of whether or not pi is a "normal" number, roughly meaning that it's digits behave like a random sequence. It was left as a conjecture in Galperin's paper on the topic. See sections 9 and 10 of that paper (linked in the description) for more details.

2) A word on terminology: I tend to use the word “phase space” to describe any space like the ones described in this video and the last, encoding some state of some system. You should know, though, that often in the context of mechanics, this term is reserved for the special case of a space which encodes both the positions and the momenta of all the objects involved. For example, in that setting, the “phase space” here would be four-dimensional, where the four coordinates represent the position and momentum of each pair of blocks. The term “configuration space”, in contrast, just refers to one where the coordinates describe the positions of all the objects involved, which is what we do next video.

There’s probably been a lot of research on this but nonetheless I find it to be a nice thought. For example, with the mass 10 we get the expansion 1.0… (because mass with 10 was 10 bounces) which makes sense, because sqrt(10) is a decent approximation to pi!

I figured out the solution by getting asked about another mathematical problem. I only know about its German term, but I guess it is called the couchproblem. I decided that the area of the L shaped form getting around the corner could be infinite, if I decided to make the length of the corridor infinite. I could just evade the angle of the L in the direction it came from until it is through, which would take an infinite amount of time. I would bump into the corner pi times I guess ;) This only shows that the perfect circle like the dot is a mathematical construct, an ideal, that is actually not found in its definition in physics. We in that regard tend to apply pi on circles, which actually are only an idealization of roundness, which reflects on the shore paradox (or what it is called anyway): the more exactly you measure, the longer the shore becomes...

Also, for anyone chuffing at the apparent violation of conservation of momentum (resulting momentum is drastically different than the initial - ie, moving the opposite direction), remember that the real world doesn't have perfectly elastic collisions or walls with infinite mass. I saw the example with a mass ratio of 64 and that got me thinking about this problem outside of base 10. Pi in base 8 is 3.1103..., so for a mass ratio of 8^2, the number of collisions is 31 in base 8, which is 25! So if the mass ratio can be expressed as b^2k, where b is an integer, then the number of collisions in base b = (pi in base b)*b^k. Or you can assume base 10 and just solve for the number of collisions, which ends up being floor(pi*10^(.5*log(n)))

Yeah this idea of casting states as points in a geometric space is pretty cool when it comes to measuring the "distance" between two probability distributions of the same family e.g. Two normal distributions with separate means and variances. By casting the mean and variances as coordinates  of a half plane, it's then quite easy(ish) to identify this half plane as isomorphic to  the poincare halfplane and show that the Fisher information provides a really nice hyperbolic metric for describing the distance between two distributions. I was amazed by this solution. I have designed digital control IC's for controlling resonant power converters using a very similar solution. The energy contained in the "resonant tank" is governed by conservation of energy and traces a circular 'energy trajectory' and the power switch events are governed by conservation of charge tracing a linear trajectory that intercepts the circular energy trajectory and provides an alternative trajectory path. I was absolutely amazed to see this almost identical solution being applied to mechanical collisions as what I have used to describe a resonant power converter.

#include <iostream>
#include <time.h>
using namespace std;

int main() {
//Calculate how much time it needs
clock_t start, finish;
double totaltime;
start = clock();

double m1 = 1.0, m2 = 1e16; //set the m2 mass as you wish
double v1 = 0, v2 = -1;
double v10, v20;
long count = 0;

while (1) {
//m2 is going to hit m1;
if (v1 > v2) {
v10 = v1, v20 = v2;
v1 = ((m1 - m2) * v10 + 2 * m2 * v20) / (m1 + m2);
v2 = ((m2 - m1) * v20 + 2 * m1 * v10) / (m1 + m2);
}
//m1 collide with wall;
else if (v1 < v2 && v1 < 0)
v1 = -v1;
//Collide is over
else
break;
count++;
//cout << "v1 = " << v1 << " v2 = " << v2 << " count = " << count << endl;
}
cout << "Total Collisions = " << count << endl;

//Calculate how much time it needs
finish = clock();
totaltime = (double)(finish - start) / CLOCKS_PER_SEC;
cout << "Calculation time: " << totaltime << "s" << endl;
}

That last problem is one that I have been thinking about for a while. It just hit me, like ten years back, that a line entering an angle of two intersecting lines, and bouncing perfectly off those lines, would always come back out from the intersection, and eventually reach an angle of exit that would forever keep it between those lines never touching them again.
The shallower the angle of entry with regards to any of the two intersecting lines, the more reflections would be required.

It's also somewhat of a dimensional problem, since you can take any angle of entry, and look at it as a later stage of a shallower angle of entry. To an extent, there has to be some limit to this, or all instances would be identical.

Since ArcTan[1/n] only approximates 1/n for large n, it follows that there are counterexamples to the approximation of Pi by physics engine.

For 1 < n < 100,000, Floor[Pi / ArcTan[1/n] ] == 1 + Floor[Pi n ] for these values:
{1, 6, 7, 2×7, 3×7, 4×7, 113, 2×113, 3×113, 4×113, 5×113, 6×113, 7×113, 8×113, 9×113, 10×113, 11×113, 12×113, 13×113, 14×113, 15×113, 16×113, 17×113, 33215, 99532}

Additional examples of n where the approximation isn't good enough are given by the denominators to the first 60 even convergents (best rational approximations) to π, Denominator[Convergents[Pi, 120][[2;;;;2]]], the largest of which is over 7×10^61. Some multiples of them also suffer defects. There appears to be a relation between the how long the sequence n, 2×n, 3×n, 4×n ... k×n continues to cause defects and the square root of the next term in the continued fraction.

When I saw the first one, I did the math myself and saw why it was so. And also found it was computationally useless as a method of easily calculating pi. What I got was this (reading off the little scrap of paper I wrote it on): So if you start with mass m moving to the left at speed v2, and mass 1 moving to the right at speed v1. So ostensibly m is some large integer power of 10 the way you presented it. And with simple physics where kinetic energy and momentum are non-relativistic and conserved, I got that it results in the mass 1 moving to the left (assumed, but on the last bounce it could be going to the right) at speed u1=(2*m*v2+(m-1)*v1)/(m+1) and the mass m still moving to the left (assumed, but of course eventually it turns around) at speed u2=((m-1)*v2-2*v1)/(m+1). Now you can see that this is just defined by a 2x2 matrix from R2 onto R2 which represents a change in magnitude and a rotation. The m+1 in the denominator doesn't MATTER, it just changes the magnitude since it is the case for BOTH of them, so you can leave that out. Remember u2 is negated when it hits the wall at x=0. And you are left with just the 2x2 matrix:
[ m-1 2m
-2 m-1]

Which for large m, is APPROXIMATELY:
[1 2
0 1]

Which unfortunately isn't really a very well conditioned matrix. But it's not REALLY bad. Nevertheless, for a LARGE number of iterations, this APPROXIMATION isn't good enough and precision is REALLY the key.

And so the question is, when you ITERATE this, i.e. you take this matrix to a high POWER, at what point does the ANGLE SHIFT of the original vector of [0 1] (the mass of 1 motionless and the mass m moving to the left at velocity 1, it doesn't matter what it is as long as it is something) get past 90 degrees (that's the point where the mass m changes direction - you might as well just find the point where it changes direction and assume that to be the halfway point)? Well if you were just using the 2nd thing, the approximation, it would NEVER happen, it would NEVER get to 90 degrees (this shouldn't be a big surprise as it means m is infinite and the mass 1 can't affect its velocity by impacting it, so it would just turn the 0 1 vector into 2 1 and then 3 1 and then 4 1 and then 5 1 and just keep going like that). Each time you're just doing this transformation, pretty soon you're just going to be doing a very slight angle shift as it just gets closer and closer and closer to being the eigenvector on [1 0], however if you stop using the APPROXIMATION, the eigenvector won't be exactly [1 0] but SLIGHTLY past that, so that it eventually crosses the 90 degree shift point but also important is that it's numerically going to be really LOUSY and the errors will add up if you try to use the method where you take the matrix to a high power.

It's not really a good way of finding pi then.

Numberphile presented this in a 2012 video. They didn't give an explanation on why this happens, and they said that "it has nothing to do with circles" (but 3Brown1Blue always finds a way to relate ANYTHING with Pi with a circle). However, what called my attention is that, while 3Brown1Blue presents a solution that works ONLY if the big mass is 100^N times the smaller mass, the Numberphile video (based on the same paper) says that it works ONLY if the big mass is 16 times 100^N times the smaller mass. So when starting with N=0, Numberphile gets a big mass of 16 times the smaller one to get the 1st digit of Pi: 3. While 3Brown1Blue gets 1 (m1=m2) to get the same first digit 3. Another difference (that I thought explained it all) was the Numberphile is counting ONLY the impacts between the 2 masses, while 3Brown1Blue is counting both the impacts between the 2 masses and between the small mass and the wall. When you explained how the number of collisions is the maximum integer multiplied by theta that is less than pi, I thought about what that would look like with blocks of equal mass. There are three collisions, with the last leaving one block stationary. On the diagram, this would look like a 45 degree line, one vertical 'jump', then one more line ending on the x axis at exactly (1,0). The lines are 45 degrees because the blocks' masses, and therefore the rise and run, are both equal. The arctan of a 1/1 slope is exactly equal to pi/4. Thus, the maximum integer in the case of equal block mass can actually be 4 while still not being above pi- just equal to it. Thinking back to the diagram, what would a 4th collision even look like? If the 3rd line is diagonal and lands on (1,0), the next line would be a 'jump', or reflection, across the x axis... Which would still be (1,0). In a '1/0 = infinity' kind of way, there 'would' be another collision 'after infinite time', but just how 1/0 does not equal infinity, there's never another collision because the block isn't moving.

Wait, can we prove that this approximation never fails? Because as small as this error gets, there is nothing stopping pi from having that amount of nines needed after the wanted digit in the decimal expansion, like
...5999...993647...
so that our approximation times the calculated value of hits is smaller than 10^n*pi, while in reality we are overshooting by one on the last digit
...5999...983955... = arctan(1/100^n) * [the approximation]
...6000...000000... = 1/100^n * [the approximation]

So we can only be sure that the number of times the small block hits the large one (M = m*100^n) is floor(10^n*pi) or floor(10^n*pi)+1 as n gets larger and larger.
